#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #1
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-06-29 18:47:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
3 hours of severe left sided chest pressure. Radiates to arm. Associated shortness of breath. Denies hx MI. Mildly
diaphoretic. Aspirin 324 per EMS.
HPI/PE:
Patient is a 68 y/o M w/ PMH HTN, HLD, CKD (not on dialysis) presenting for eval chest pain. Reports
chest pain started approximately 3 hours. Pressure-like, exertional Radiates to L shoulder. Does not
radiate to back. No ripping/tearing quality. Non-pleuritic. Associated with some SOB that worsens when
laying flat.
Denies prior hx ACS. Denies family hx early cardiovascular disease.
Does not see a cardiologist.
No hx DVT/PE. No hx recent surgery, immobilization, hormones. No smoking.
No fevers, chills, infectious symptoms.
MDM:
68M with risk factors and chest pain concerning for ACS. Initial troponin noted to be markedly elevated.
No history of prior troponin in chart. ECG no ST segment changes but some LVH. Cardiology consulted,
recommends serial troponin/ECG and admission. Low clinical suspicion for DVT/PE. No pneumonia/pnx
on CXR. Got aspirin pre-hospital. Heparin. Hold off on Brilinta per cardiology. Adm.
Physical Exam
ED Triage Vitals [06/29/23 1422]
BP: (!) 163/95
Pulse: (!) 115
Pulse from O2 sat: n/a
Resp: 22
Temp: 99.1 °F (37.3 °C)
Temp src: Oral
SpO2: 97%

Physical Exam
Procedures

Clinical Impressions as of 06/29/23 1531
NSTEMI (non-ST elevated myocardial infarction) (HC Code) (HC CODE) (HC Code)
ED Disposition
Admit

ENCOUNTER NOTE #2
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-06-29 18:37:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Registered Nurse


02:25 PM Pt w/ 3 hours chest pain, diaphoretic, uncomfortable appearing. NC O2 for comfort. Pt aox4,
vss. Steady gait. 8/10 chest pain. Radiates to shoulder. Aspirin by EMS. Tech getting EKG.

The encounter diagnosis was Flank pain.
Plan
Given intermittent flank pain without clear laterality concern for possible renal vs MSK vs aortic
etiology. Low suspicion for aortic dissection. Doubt surgical emergency. Recommended renal
ultrasound to patient however ultrasound has already closed for the day. Patient does not want to
wait overnight for ultrasound to open in the morning. Would rather go home with close PMD follow-
up. Counseled on risks of leaving without definitive workup, after shared ecision making patient
understyands risk. Doubt life-threatening process. Counseled on return precautions.

Discharge

ENCOUNTER NOTE #4
((PAST Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-06-14 16:17:00
Type: ED Visit 
Provider: Registered Nurse


2:20 PM Patient arrives to ED for eval of flank pain x 2 days. Some blood in urine. No fevers, chills, chest
pain, shortness of breath. In no acute distress. Needs to get home soon to take care of grandkids.
2:43 PM MD at bedside. Plan of care explained to patient, will need ultrasounds.
2:45 PM Called ultrasound to schedule, closed for day. MD on phone with radiologist figuring out when
ultrasound can get done.
2:50 PM MD at bedside explaining ultrasound can’t be done until 9am tomorrow because lab is down.
3:34 PM MD at bedside discharging patient. VSS, ambulatory with steady gait. Patient verbalized
understanding and acceptance of discharge instructions. Discharged to home. All belongings returned to
patient.

ENCOUNTER NOTE #6
((PAST Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2022-09-01 16:37:00
Type: PCP Visit
Provider: Physician


Urgent Visit: 

A 68-year-old gentleman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents for recurrence of shortness of breath. He first had symptoms 3 weeks ago. He was treated with antibiotics and finish antibiotic course on August 16th. He reports continued nasal congestion, cough, production of sputum, shortness of breath, wheezing and subjective fevers/chills. He also reports some headaches. No nausea, vomiting or diarrhea. 

BP 122/07 | Pulse (!) 90 | Temp 97.8 °F (36.6 °C) | Resp 20 | SpO2 98% 

In no acute distress lungs are clear to auscultation Regular heart rate and rhythm. The abdomen is soft and non distended Assessment plan: A 68-year-old gentleman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents for recurrence of nasal congestion. I am going to obtain a respiratory viral panel, sputum culture and chest x ray. I am concerned about a pneumonia. I will start antibiotics and call him back with his lab results.

hist_gptResponse: The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease. He presented to the ED with severe left-sided chest pain radiating to the arm, shortness of breath, and was mildly diaphoretic. His pain was pressure-like and worsened with exertion. His initial troponin was markedly elevated and his ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no ST segment changes. He was diagnosed with a non-ST elevated myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and admitted for further management. Given these symptoms, lab findings, and the diagnosis of NSTEMI, the patient's history is highly suspicious for a cardiac event. [Highly suspicious (2)]

 [Normal (0)] [Non-specific repolarization disturbance (1)] [Significant ST deviation (2)] [Not enough information to determine EKG score]

ENCOUNTER NOTE #1
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-06-29 18:47:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
3 hours of severe left sided chest pressure. Radiates to arm. Associated shortness of breath. Denies hx MI. Mildly
diaphoretic. Aspirin 324 per EMS.
HPI/PE:
Patient is a 68 y/o M w/ PMH HTN, HLD, CKD (not on dialysis) presenting for eval chest pain. Reports
chest pain started approximately 3 hours. Pressure-like, exertional Radiates to L shoulder. Does not
radiate to back. No ripping/tearing quality. Non-pleuritic. Associated with some SOB that worsens when
laying flat.
Denies prior hx ACS. Denies family hx early cardiovascular disease.
Does not see a cardiologist.
No hx DVT/PE. No hx recent surgery, immobilization, hormones. No smoking.
No fevers, chills, infectious symptoms.
MDM:
68M with risk factors and chest pain concerning for ACS. Initial troponin noted to be markedly elevated.
No history of prior troponin in chart. ECG no ST segment changes but some LVH. Cardiology consulted,
recommends serial troponin/ECG and admission. Low clinical suspicion for DVT/PE. No pneumonia/pnx
on CXR. Got aspirin pre-hospital. Heparin. Hold off on Brilinta per cardiology. Adm.
Physical Exam
ED Triage Vitals [06/29/23 1422]

Pulse: (!) 115
Pulse from O2 sat: n/a

Temp: 99.1 °F (37.3 °C)

Physical Exam

NSTEMI (non-ST elevated myocardial infarction) (HC Code) (HC CODE) (HC Code)

Admit

Last Edited: 2023-06-29 18:37:00

Provider: Registered Nurse


02:25 PM Pt w/ 3 hours chest pain, diaphoretic, uncomfortable appearing. NC O2 for comfort. Pt aox4,

Type: ED Visit

Urgent Visit: 

A 68-year-old gentleman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents for recurrence of shortness of breath. He first had symptoms 3 weeks ago. He was treated with antibiotics and finish antibiotic course on August 16th. He reports continued nasal congestion, cough, production of sputum, shortness of breath, wheezing and subjective fevers/chills. He also reports some headaches. No nausea, vomiting or diarrhea. 

BP 122/07 | Pulse (!) 90 | Temp 97.8 °F (36.6 °C) | Resp 20 | SpO2 98% 

In no acute distress lungs are clear to auscultation Regular heart rate and rhythm. The abdomen is soft and non distended Assessment plan: A 68-year-old gentleman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents for recurrence of nasal congestion. I am going to obtain a respiratory viral panel, sputum culture and chest x ray. I am concerned about a pneumonia. I will start antibiotics and call him back with his lab results.

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease. He presented with severe left-sided chest pressure radiating to his arm, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. These symptoms are concerning for acute coronary syndrome (ACS). His troponin levels were markedly elevated, and his EKG showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no ST segment changes. The patient was diagnosed with non-ST elevated myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and was admitted for further management. Given the patient's age, past medical history, and presenting symptoms, there is a high suspicion of a cardiac event. 

[Highly suspicious (2)]

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease. He presented with severe left-sided chest pressure that radiated to his arm, associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. These symptoms are classic for acute coronary syndrome (ACS). His initial troponin was markedly elevated, further supporting the diagnosis of ACS. The EKG did not show ST segment changes, but there was evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient was given aspirin and heparin, and cardiology was consulted. The patient was admitted for further management. Given the patient's symptoms, history, and initial lab results, there is a high suspicion of a cardiac event.

[Highly suspicious (2)]

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease. He presented with severe left-sided chest pressure radiating to the arm, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. His symptoms are exertional and worsen when lying flat. He has no history of acute coronary syndrome or early cardiovascular disease in the family. His initial troponin levels were markedly elevated, and his ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no ST-segment changes. He was diagnosed with non-ST elevated myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and admitted for further management. 

Given the patient's age, medical history, presenting symptoms, and diagnostic findings, his history is highly suspicious for a cardiac event. 

[Highly suspicious (2)]

He presented with severe left-sided chest pressure that radiated to his arm, associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. These symptoms are typical of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The patient's troponin levels were markedly elevated, which is indicative of myocardial injury. His EKG showed no ST segment changes but some left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient was diagnosed with a non-ST elevated myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and was admitted for further management. Given the patient's age, past medical history, and the nature and severity of his symptoms, his history is highly suspicious for a cardiac event. [Highly suspicious (2)]

The patient's elevated troponin levels and the physician's clinical impression of NSTEMI (non-ST elevated myocardial infarction) further support this suspicion. Although the patient denies a history of myocardial infarction or ACS, his age and existing comorbidities place him at high risk for cardiac events. 

[Highly suspicious (2)]

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease. His initial troponin level was markedly elevated, further supporting the suspicion of ACS. The ECG showed no ST segment changes but some left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient was given aspirin and heparin, and cardiology was consulted. The final clinical impression was non-ST elevated myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). The patient was admitted for further management. 

[Highly suspicious (2)]

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease. He presented with severe left-sided chest pressure radiating to the arm, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. His symptoms are exertional and worsen when lying flat. He has no history of acute coronary syndrome or early cardiovascular disease in the family. He was diagnosed with NSTEMI (non-ST elevated myocardial infarction) and admitted for further management. These findings are highly suggestive of a cardiac event. 

[Highly suspicious (2)]

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease. He presented with severe left-sided chest pain radiating to the arm, shortness of breath, and was mildly diaphoretic. His chest pain was pressure-like and worsened with exertion. His initial troponin levels were markedly elevated, and he was diagnosed with NSTEMI (non-ST elevated myocardial infarction). His ECG showed no ST segment changes but some left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient was given aspirin and heparin, and was admitted to the hospital. Given the patient's age, medical history, and presenting symptoms, as well as the elevated troponin levels and diagnosis of NSTEMI, this patient's history is highly suspicious for cardiac disease. 

[Highly suspicious (2)]

His initial troponin level was significantly elevated, and he had no history of prior troponin in his chart. Although his ECG showed no ST segment changes, it did show left ventricular hypertrophy. Given these findings, the patient's history is highly suspicious for a cardiac event. [Highly suspicious (2)]

He presented with severe left-sided chest pressure radiating to his arm, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. These symptoms are classic for acute coronary syndrome (ACS). His initial troponin was markedly elevated, and he was diagnosed with a non-ST elevated myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). His EKG showed left ventricular hypertrophy but no ST segment changes. Given his age, medical history, and presenting symptoms, there is a high suspicion of a cardiac event. [Highly suspicious (2)]

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 50-year-old male who presented with right-sided chest pain that started after using a rowing machine at the gym. He has no significant past medical history and no family history of myocardial infarction. His pain is described as sharp and more towards the shoulder than the chest. Physical examination revealed tenderness over the right anterior rotator cuff. The EKG showed no ischemic changes and the troponin level was normal. The patient's chest pain improved significantly after the application of a lidocaine patch. The medical team suspects the pain to be mechanical in nature, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury. 

Given the patient's age, the nature of the pain, the absence of risk factors for coronary artery disease, the normal EKG and troponin level, and the improvement with a lidocaine patch, the suspicion for a cardiac etiology for the chest pain is low. 

[ Slightly suspicious (0) ]

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 50-year-old male with no significant past medical history, who presented with right-sided chest pain after using a rowing machine at the gym. The pain is described as sharp, more on the shoulder than the chest, and is tender to palpation over the right anterior rotator cuff. The patient denies shortness of breath and radiation of pain. The EKG was non-ischemic without any ST segment changes, and troponin levels were normal. The patient's pain improved after a lidocaine patch was applied. The patient has no personal or family history of heart problems. The suspected cause of the chest pain is mechanical, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury. 

Given the patient's age, lack of significant past medical history, the nature and location of the pain, the improvement with lidocaine, and the normal EKG and troponin levels, the patient's history is not highly suspicious for a cardiac event. 

[Slightly suspicious (0)]

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 50-year-old male with no significant past medical history. He presented with right-sided chest pain that started after using a rowing machine at the gym. The pain is described as sharp and is more localized to the shoulder than the chest. The patient denies shortness of breath and radiation of pain. Physical examination revealed tenderness over the right anterior rotator cuff. The patient has no personal or family history of heart problems. An EKG showed no signs of ischemia or ST segment changes. The patient's troponin levels were also normal. The chest pain is suspected to be mechanical in nature, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury. The patient's symptoms improved after a lidocaine patch was applied. 

Given the patient's presentation, normal EKG and troponin levels, and improvement of symptoms with a lidocaine patch, the history is not highly suspicious for a cardiac event. However, the presence of chest pain, even if it is suspected to be mechanical, warrants some level of suspicion. 

[Moderately suspicious (1)]

Patient is a 50M w/ no sig PMH here w/ CP.

because his PCP has been getting him to lose weight. Reports losing 10 pounds over the last 2 months,
no longer overweight. Denies shortness of breath. Denies radiation of pain.
Describes pain as sharp, R sided, more shoulder than chest.
No history of prior shoulder injuries or rotator cuff injuries. Tender to palpation over the R anterior
rotator cuff.
No personal history of heart problems. No one in his family has had an MI.
MDM:
50M here w/ CP suspected to be mechanical in etiology. Considered ACS, however EKG non-ischemic
without any ST segment changes. Will get troponin and reassess. Doubt DVT/PE
Low suspicion for shoulder fracture or other emergent MSK process. May be related to rotator cuff
injury, however no emergent treatment would be indicated. Will try lidocaine patch and advice RICE for
now and have him follow up with PMD if his shoulder pain doesn’t get better.
Case discussed with attending physician.

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 50-year-old male with no significant past medical history, who presented with right-sided chest pain that started after using a rowing machine at the gym. The pain was sharp and more towards the shoulder than the chest. There was no shortness of breath or radiation of pain. The patient had no personal or family history of heart problems. Physical examination revealed tenderness over the right anterior rotator cuff. EKG was non-ischemic without any ST segment changes and troponin levels were normal. The pain improved with a lidocaine patch. The chest pain was suspected to be mechanical in etiology, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury. There was low suspicion for acute coronary syndrome, pulmonary embolism, or shoulder fracture. 

Given the patient's age, lack of significant past medical history, lack of risk factors for cardiac disease, the nature and location of the pain, and the normal EKG and troponin levels, the patient's history is [Slightly suspicious (0)] for a cardiac etiology of the chest pain.

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 50-year-old male who presented with right-sided chest pain that started after using a rowing machine at the gym. He has no significant past medical history and no family history of heart problems. The pain is described as sharp, more in the shoulder than the chest, and is tender to palpation over the right anterior rotator cuff. The EKG was non-ischemic without any ST segment changes, and his troponin levels were normal. The medical team suspects the pain to be mechanical in nature, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury. 

Given the patient's age, the nature and location of the pain, the absence of other cardiac symptoms such as shortness of breath, the normal EKG and troponin levels, and the fact that the pain started during physical activity, it seems less likely that this is a cardiac event. However, chest pain in a 50-year-old male should not be completely ignored as a potential cardiac symptom. 

[Moderately suspicious (1)]

The pain is described as sharp, located more in the shoulder than the chest, and tender to palpation over the right anterior rotator cuff. The patient has no personal or family history of heart problems. The EKG showed no signs of ischemia and the troponin level was normal. The patient's pain improved with a lidocaine patch. The medical team suspects the pain is mechanical in nature, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury. 

Given the patient's age, the nature and location of the pain, the lack of cardiac risk factors, and the negative cardiac workup, the patient's history is [Slightly suspicious (0)].

He has no significant past medical history, no personal history of heart problems, and no family history of myocardial infarction. His EKG was non-ischemic without any ST segment changes, and his troponin levels were normal. The chest pain is suspected to be mechanical in etiology, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury. The patient's vital signs were stable and his physical exam was largely unremarkable. He was discharged with instructions to follow up with his primary care provider if his shoulder pain doesn't improve. 

Given this information, the patient's history is [Slightly suspicious (0)]. The patient's symptoms are more consistent with a musculoskeletal issue rather than a cardiac one, and his EKG and troponin levels do not indicate a cardiac event.

The pain is described as sharp, more on the shoulder than the chest, and there is tenderness on palpation over the right anterior rotator cuff. He has no history of heart problems or any family history of myocardial infarction. His EKG was non-ischemic without any ST segment changes, and his troponin levels were normal. The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with his primary care provider if his shoulder pain doesn't improve. 

Given the patient's presentation, the lack of cardiac risk factors, and the improvement in symptoms with a lidocaine patch, the patient's history is [Slightly suspicious (0)].

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 50-year-old male who presented with right-sided chest pain that started while he was using a rowing machine at the gym. He has no significant past medical history and no family history of myocardial infarction. His pain is described as sharp, more on the shoulder than the chest, and it is tender to palpation over the right anterior rotator cuff. His EKG showed no ischemic changes and his troponin levels were normal. The patient's pain improved after a lidocaine patch was applied. The physician's differential diagnosis included, but doubted, acute coronary syndrome, pulmonary embolism, and fracture. The physician favored a mild sprain of the shoulder but did not exclude a more serious rotator cuff injury. 

Given the patient's age, the nature of the pain, the absence of shortness of breath, the normal EKG and troponin levels, and the improvement with lidocaine patch, the suspicion for a cardiac etiology of the chest pain is low. However, the patient was exercising when the pain started, which could increase suspicion for a cardiac cause. 

[Slightly suspicious (0)]

The patient has no history of heart problems or any family history of myocardial infarction. An EKG showed no ischemic changes and the troponin level was less than 6. The patient is a 50-year-old male with no significant past medical history who presented with right-sided chest pain that started after using a rowing machine at the gym. The pain is described as sharp, more on the shoulder than the chest, and is tender to palpation over the right anterior rotator cuff. There is no history of shoulder injuries or rotator cuff injuries. The patient denies any shortness of breath or radiation of pain. He has no personal or family history of heart problems. His EKG was non-ischemic without any ST segment changes and his troponin level was less than 6. The patient's pain improved after a lidocaine patch was applied. The medical team suspects a mechanical etiology for the chest pain, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury. The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician if his shoulder pain does not improve. 

Given the patient's age, lack of significant past medical history, absence of cardiac risk factors, and the nature and location of the pain, the history is [Slightly suspicious (0)].

The patient is a 50-year-old male with no significant past medical history who presented with right-sided chest pain that started after using a rowing machine at the gym. The pain is described as sharp and more towards the shoulder than the chest. There is no history of shortness of breath, radiation of pain, or previous heart problems. Physical examination revealed tenderness over the right anterior rotator cuff. The EKG was non-ischemic without any ST segment changes, and the troponin level was less than 6. The pain improved with a lidocaine patch. Given these findings, the chest pain is suspected to be mechanical in etiology, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury, rather than cardiac in origin. 

[Moderately suspicious (1)]

His physical examination was unremarkable except for tenderness over the right anterior rotator cuff. The pain improved with a lidocaine patch. The patient is a 50-year-old male who presented with right-sided chest pain that started while he was using a rowing machine at the gym. He has no significant past medical history and no family history of myocardial infarction. He denied shortness of breath and the pain did not radiate. The pain was described as sharp and was more on the shoulder than the chest. On examination, there was tenderness over the right anterior rotator cuff. EKG showed no ischemic changes and troponin levels were normal. The pain improved with a lidocaine patch. The patient was discharged with advice to follow up with his primary care provider if his shoulder pain doesn't get better. 

Given the patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, and test results, his history is not highly suspicious for a cardiac event. The pain seems to be more related to a possible musculoskeletal issue, possibly related to his exercise at the gym.

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 50-year-old male who presented with right-sided chest pain after using a rowing machine at the gym. He has no significant past medical history or family history of heart problems. His pain is described as sharp and more towards the shoulder than the chest. He denies shortness of breath and the pain does not radiate. His physical examination was unremarkable, with normal heart sounds and normal breath sounds. His EKG did not show any signs of ischemia and his troponin levels were normal. The pain improved with the application of a lidocaine patch. The medical team suspects the pain to be mechanical in nature, possibly related to a rotator cuff injury. 

Given this information, the patient's history is not highly suggestive of a cardiac etiology for his chest pain. His symptoms improved with a lidocaine patch, which suggests a musculoskeletal cause rather than a cardiac one. His EKG and troponin levels were also normal, which further reduces the likelihood of a cardiac cause. 

[Slightly suspicious (0)]

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 50-year-old male with no significant past medical history who presented with right-sided chest pain after using a rowing machine. The pain is described as sharp, more in the shoulder than the chest, and is tender to palpation over the right anterior rotator cuff. The patient denies shortness of breath and radiation of pain. There is no personal or family history of heart problems. The EKG was non-ischemic without any ST segment changes and the troponin level was normal. The patient's pain improved with a lidocaine patch. The clinical impression is that the chest pain is likely mechanical in origin, possibly related to a mild sprain or rotator cuff injury. 

Given the patient's presentation, the absence of risk factors for cardiac disease, the normal EKG and troponin level, and the improvement with a lidocaine patch, the suspicion for a cardiac cause of the chest pain is low. 

[Slightly suspicious (0)]

#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #1
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-08-01 16:37:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
Pain started after breakfast about 9am, L sided, +pleuritic, no hx PE but thinks family hx. No fevers/infectious.
EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.
Physical Exam
ED Triage Vitals [08/01/23 1209]
BP: 118/63
Pulse: (!) 103
Pulse from O2 sat: n/a
Resp: 25
Temp: 98.3 °F (36.8°C)

Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
Pain started after breakfast about 9am, L sided, +pleuritic, no hx PE but thinks family hx. No fevers/infectious.
EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.

is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.

pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.

cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 54-year-old female with a history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus type II, and tobacco use disorder. She presented with left-sided chest pain that radiated to her neck and worsened with deep breaths. She also had mild nausea but no vomiting. The patient has a family history of pulmonary embolism but no personal history of thromboembolic disease. Her EKG showed a new left bundle branch block, and her troponin levels were mildly elevated but stable. Her chest pain resolved after administration of aspirin and nitroglycerin. Given her age, past medical history, and symptoms, this patient has a moderate risk of having a cardiac event. Her symptoms and EKG findings are concerning for possible cardiac ischemia. However, her chest pain resolved with nitroglycerin and aspirin, and her troponin levels were only mildly elevated. Therefore, while her history is concerning, it is not definitive for a cardiac event. 

[Moderately suspicious (1)]

is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),

Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with

thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode

use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.

noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited

She presented with left-sided chest pain that radiated to her neck, worsened with deep breaths, and was associated with mild nausea. HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

Consider the following risk factors: HTN, hypercholesterolemia, DM, obesity (BMI >30 kg/m²), smoking (current, or smoking cessation ≤3 mo), positive family history (parent or sibling with CVD before age 65); atherosclerotic disease: prior MI, PCI/CABG, CVA/TIA, or peripheral arterial disease. 
 
 For the patient below, across all the combined encounter notes, how many risk factors are present? 
 [No known risk factors (0)] [1-2 risk factors (1)] [>= 3 risk factors or history of atherosclerotic disease (2)] [Not enough information to determine Risk Factor score]
 
 Please first explain your reasoning and then provide your final choice, listing one option between the answers above in brackets (e.g. [No known risk factors (0)] ).
 
#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #1
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-08-01 16:37:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Chest Pain
Pain started after breakfast about 9am, L sided, +pleuritic, no hx PE but thinks family hx. No fevers/infectious.
EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.
Physical Exam
ED Triage Vitals [08/01/23 1209]
BP: 118/63
Pulse: (!) 103
Pulse from O2 sat: n/a
Resp: 25
Temp: 98.3 °F (36.8°C)
Temp src: Temporal
SpO2: 97%
BP 118/63| Pulse (!) 103 | Temp 98.3 °F (36.8°C) (Temporal) | Resp 25 | Wt 148.3 kg
Physical Exam
Constitutional
Appearance: Normal appearance. No acute distress.
HENT:
Head: Normocephalic and atraumatic
Eyes:
Conjunctiva/sclera: Conjunctivae normal. Sclera non-icteric.
Cardiovascular:
Rate and Rhythm: Tachycardic rate and regular rhythm.
Pulses: Decreased pulses (difficult to palpate pulses in radial, DP, PT).
Heart sounds: Normal heart sounds.
Pulmonary:
Effort: Pulmonary effort is increased.
Breath sounds: Normal breath sounds.
Abdominal:
General: Bowel sounds are normal.
Palpations: Abdomen is soft.
Tenderness: Abdomen is nontender. There is no left or right CVA tenderness.
Skin:
General: Skin is warm and dry.
Neurological:
General: No focal deficit present.
Procedures
Attestation/Critical Care
Clinical Impressions as of 08/01/23 15:53
Chest pain, unspecified type
ED Disposition
Observation


#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #2
((CURRENT Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-08-01 16:11:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Registered Nurse


12:24 PM 54F with several hours of left sided chest pain. Radiates to neck. +pleuritic. Reports several of
her family have had PEs in the past but doesn’t think she has had one. No cough, fever, SOB. No hx MI.
Received aspirin and EKG at triage. Labs/IV. Placed on monitor, side rails in place, call bell in reach.
01:03 PM Chest pain still persistent 5/10, MD aware, nitroglycerin administered per MAR.
01:25 PM Patient reports continued chest pain 4/10, MD notified no new orders at this time.
02:41 PM Chest pain is now resolved. No other new or worsening symptoms.
03:45 PM Per d/w MD patient will be admitted to chest pain center for stress test tomorrow. Handover
provided to CPC RN.
04:05 PM Patient transported to CPC further care deferred to CPC RN.


#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #3
((PAST Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-07-23 19:30:00
Type: ED Visit 
Provider: Registered Nurse


6:26 PM Pt arrives from radiology after getting L ankle XR to r/o fx after accidentally dropping knife on
foot. She was at work cutting onions when the accident happened. Registration at bedside providing
workman’s comp pamphlet. Tetanus UTD.
6:49 PM Laceration repair by MD at bedside.
7:16 PM Patient discharged after completion of lac repair. Pain controlled. Has a safe ride home. Denies
any additional concerns. All questions addressed by provider. Ambulatory to WR w/ steady gait.


#####################################
ENCOUNTER NOTE #4
((PAST Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-07-23 19:17:00
Type: ED Visit
Provider: Physician


Chief Complaint
Patient presents with
• Laceration
Slicing onions and dropped cleaver on L foot. Bleeding controlled in field by EMS. No thinners. TDAP UTD.
HPI/PE:
Ms. is a 54F with PMH PAD presenting for a laceration.
was in the kitchen today chopping onions at work when she lost control of the knife and dropped in
onto her left foot. She was wearing closed-toes shoes however sustained a deep laceration over the
anterior L ankle. She controlled bleeding with a towel until EMS arrived and applied a pressure dressing.
She denies pulsatile bleeding.
Denies any other injuries.
Her last tetanus was 3 years ago.
The knife had not been used on any meat prior to the injury.
She doesn’t think she lost much blood at the scene.
She does report a history of LE PAD. She follows with Dr. (Burmingham Vascular Group) and report she
has had some “stents done” but doesn’t have any records.
MDM:
This is a 54 y/o F presenting to the ED for evaluation of a laceration. Wound was thoroughly irrigated
with saline and there was no evidence of joint involvement on thorough probing. An ankle x-ray was
obtained and did not demonstrate any underlying fracture. DP/PT are palpable, doubt vascular injury.
Intact neurologic status. Will repair and DC with PMD follow-up for suture removal. Strict return
precautions for signs of wound infection given. No indication for antibiotics given clean wound.
Physical Exam
ED Triage Vitals [07/23/23 1804]
BP: 121/75
Pulse: (!) 128
Pulse from O2 sat: n/a
Resp: (!) 28
Temp: 98.1 °F (36.7°C)
Temp src: Temporal
SpO2: 100%
BP 121/75| Pulse (!) 128 | Temp 98.1 °F (36.7°C) (Temporal) | Resp (!) 28 | Wt 74.1 kg
Physical Exam
Constitutional
Appearance: Normal appearance.
Cardiovascular:
Rate and Rhythm: Normal rate and regular rhythm.
Pulses: Normal pulses.
Heart sounds: Normal heart sounds.
Pulmonary:
Effort: Pulmonary effort is normal.
Breath sounds: Normal breath sounds.
Extremity:
MSK: Tenderness is present. (Laceration over L ankle with no exposed bone/tendon/joint.)
Procedures
See separately dictated procedure note.
Attestation/Critical Care
Clinical Impressions as of 07/23/23 1912
Laceration
ED Disposition
Discharge

((PAST Visit Encounter Note))

Last Edited: 2023-01-01 16:17:00
Type: PCP Visit
Provider: Physician


S: 54 yo presents for problem visit
Pt reporting that over the past month, she has had significant pain in her soles first thing in the morning.
She says that with her leg pain, it has been very difficult to walk much and she has been staying in bed or
on the couch more. She noticed that over the past month, when she first stands in the morning, her
bilateral soles “hurt like burning” and often she has to sit back down. She stats that “it feels like my feet
are on fire and tearing up”, very discouraged as her “legs hurt with walking and feet hurt with standing”.
Patient Active Problem List
Tobacco use
Type 2 diabetes mellitus, without long-term current use of insulin
Other obesity due to excess calories
Peripheral vascular disease
O:
Vitals:
BP: 122/82
Pulse: 70
Temp: 98.2 °F (36.8 °C)
Constitutional: well appearing
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI
CV: RRR
Pulm: CTAB
Neuro: AOx3
A/P: Plantar fasciitis
- Patient reassured, referred to PT

Additionally, the patient is obese with a weight of 148.3 kg. Therefore, the patient has at least 4 risk factors for cardiovascular disease.

Final choice: [>= 3 risk factors or history of atherosclerotic disease (2)]

You are a cardiologist reviewing a patient's history during their current cardiac ED visit. Please be concise.

 [Slightly suspicious (0)] [Moderately suspicious (1)] [Highly suspicious (2)] [Not enough information to determine History score]

Chief Complaint

HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

hist_gptResponse:
The patient is a 54-year-old woman with a history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II), and tobacco use disorder, presenting with left-sided chest pain that radiates to her neck and worsens with deep respirations. She also has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. The EKG showed a new left bundle branch block of unclear chronicity and her troponin levels were mildly elevated but stable. The chest pain resolved after administration of aspirin and nitroglycerin. Given the patient's history and symptoms, there is a moderate suspicion of cardiac etiology, particularly ischemic heart disease. The patient's risk factors (age, diabetes, smoking, and peripheral artery disease) and symptoms (chest pain radiating to the neck, new left bundle branch block on EKG, and mildly elevated troponin) are concerning for cardiac ischemia. However, her chest pain resolved with nitroglycerin and aspirin, and she is scheduled for further evaluation with a stress test. 

[Moderately suspicious (1)]

pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of

precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.

She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

Chief Complaint

EKG+aspirin given
HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

Chief Complaint

HPI/PE:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of
her chest and radiates into her neck. She denies radiation to the back. Describes as sharp. Worsens with
deep respirations. Some mild nausea, though denies vomiting.
She denies any known history of CAD. She does not believe she has ever had a stress test and no records
of stress testing are noted in our EMR.
She has a strong family history of pulmonary embolism. She does not have a personal history of
thromboembolic disease, though there was a question of a potential primary thrombotic episode
precipitating a prior episode of limb ischemia, though she was not able to further clarify. She denies OCP
use, recent surgery, long distance travel, or trauma. She has not had any unilateral leg swelling or pain.
She denies hemoptysis.
She denies any new medications.
She denies recreational drug use including cocaine.
No fevers, chills, or systemic infectious symptoms. She initially denied shortness of breath though was
noted to be tachypneic on exam.
MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

Mrs. presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. She reports that her chest
pain started this morning shortly after finishing her breakfast. The chest pain localizes to the left side of

MDM:
is a 54 y/o woman with past medical history of peripheral artery disease, diabetes mellitus (type II),
tobacco use disorder (2+ PPD) presenting for evaluation of chest pain.
A broad differential was considered for the etiology of her chest pain. Given her strong family history of
pulmonary embolism, this was a strong possibility, and a d-dimer was obtained to further assess and was
found to be within normal range. For this reason, PE is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms. Chest
radiography was obtained and did not demonstrate any evidence of pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Considered other infectious etiologies given her pleuritic chest pain, however she has had no fevers or
cough making this less likely. Her ECG was noted to show a new left bundle branch block of unclear
chronicity. Troponin mildly elevated but stable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended expedited
stress testing. Given chest pain has resolved with aspirin/nitro, will refer to chest pain center for further
evaluation of potential ischemic etiologies.

Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# RLE wound
1 week ago, the patient scratched her shin and obtained an small abrasion. She has since been working in
her garden a lot, and noticed that her abrasion is not healing. She thinks that it is getting larger, redder
and more painful. Has been putting some antibiotic ointment on it and wrapping it tightly, thinks that is is
now also oozing. Denies trying any medications for it. Has not had anything like this before.
- no fevers at home
- has with some palpitations at baseline due to anxiety
- denies lighteadeness or dizziness
- denies falls
C/f cellulitis
Start antibiotics with doxy and Keflex
F/u 1 week
If not improving, go the ED

SOCIAL HISTORY: Denies smoking, alcohol or illicits
Allergies :is allergic to penicillins - tolerates cephalosporins.

• acetaminophen (TYLENOL) 500
mg tablet
Take 2 tablets (1,000 mg total) by mouth
every 6 (six) hours as needed.

capsule

General: NAD

CV: rrr, normal s1 and s2, no murmur
Resp: CTABL, not tachypneic or in respiratory distress
Neuro: alert and oriented x4, no focal weakness
MSK/Skin: No peripheral edema, large red, swollen wound on RLE, TTP
ASSESSMENT/PLAN
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED
- CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP
- Start doxycycline and Keflex
- f/u in 1 week to evaluate wound. If the wound has wider area of involvement, or if pain is worsening,
or if there is more drainage, would consider referral to the ED for more expedited workup and
consideration of IV antibiotics
- patient agreeable with plan of care

significant cardiovascular risk factors, she has a very concerning family history and a markedly abnormal

ray was obtained to assess for alternative etiologies and was unremarkable. Initial troponin noted to be
elevated though declining. Pain also resolved. Cardiology consulted, plan for admission for further
cardiac w/u.

is a 38 y/o woman with no significant PMH presenting to the ED for evaluation of chest pain.
She reports that her chest pain started while she was making breakfast about an hour ago and has been
continuous since then. Pressure-like. Describes like “someone sitting on my chest”. Associated nausea,
no vomiting or diarrhea. Pain radiates into her left shoulder and neck. She reports multiple episodes of
similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency. Had trouble sleeping last night due to pain.
Has been having some exertional dyspnea climbing stairs for the last few weeks.
She denies any other shortness of breath.
No fevers, chills, or other infectious symptoms.
She does not have a personal history of CAD however she reports her mother had a heart attack when
she was 42 and her father died suddenly at 50.
She denies any history of DVT/PE.
She has a primary care doctor but hasn’t seen them recently. Has never seen a cardiologist. No prior
stress testing.
She received aspirin prior to my assessment and had an ECG performed by EMS which shows t-wave
inversions in the anterior leads.
MDM:
presents to the ED for evaluation of chest pain. While she has a limited medical history without
significant cardiovascular risk factors, she has a very concerning family history and a markedly abnormal
ECG. Given these considerations, I have high suspicion for ACS as the etiology of her chest pain. Chest x-
ray was obtained to assess for alternative etiologies and was unremarkable. Initial troponin noted to be
elevated though declining. Pain also resolved. Cardiology consulted, plan for admission for further
cardiac w/u.

# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# RLE wound
1 week ago, the patient scratched her shin and obtained an small abrasion. She has since been working in
her garden a lot, and noticed that her abrasion is not healing. She thinks that it is getting larger, redder
and more painful. Has been putting some antibiotic ointment on it and wrapping it tightly, thinks that is is
now also oozing. Denies trying any medications for it. Has not had anything like this before.
- no fevers at home
- has with some palpitations at baseline due to anxiety
- denies lighteadeness or dizziness
- denies falls
C/f cellulitis
Start antibiotics with doxy and Keflex
F/u 1 week
If not improving, go the ED
Review of Systems
As per HPI
____________________________________________________________________________
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: She has a past medical history of Anxiety (since childhood)
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: None
FAMILY HISTORY: family history includes heart disease in her mother
SOCIAL HISTORY: Denies smoking, alcohol or illicits
Allergies :is allergic to penicillins - tolerates cephalosporins.
Medications:
• acetaminophen (TYLENOL) 500
mg tablet
Take 2 tablets (1,000 mg total) by mouth
every 6 (six) hours as needed.
• hydrOXYzine (VISTARIL) 100 mg
capsule
TAKE ONE CAPSULE BY MOUTH FOUR TIMES DAILY AS
NEEDED FOR ITCHING OR anxiety
PHYSICAL EXAM
Vitals:
BP: 120/62
Pulse: 76
Resp: 17
Temp: 98.9 °F (37.2 °C)
General: NAD
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI
CV: rrr, normal s1 and s2, no murmur
Resp: CTABL, not tachypneic or in respiratory distress
Neuro: alert and oriented x4, no focal weakness
MSK/Skin: No peripheral edema, large red, swollen wound on RLE, TTP
ASSESSMENT/PLAN
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED
- CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP
- Start doxycycline and Keflex
- f/u in 1 week to evaluate wound. If the wound has wider area of involvement, or if pain is worsening,
or if there is more drainage, would consider referral to the ED for more expedited workup and
consideration of IV antibiotics
- patient agreeable with plan of care

no vomiting or diarrhea. Pain radiates into her left shoulder and neck. She reports multiple episodes of
similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency. Had trouble sleeping last night due to pain.
Has been having some exertional dyspnea climbing stairs for the last few weeks.
She denies any other shortness of breath.
No fevers, chills, or other infectious symptoms.
She does not have a personal history of CAD however she reports her mother had a heart attack when
she was 42 and her father died suddenly at 50.
She denies any history of DVT/PE.
She has a primary care doctor but hasn’t seen them recently. Has never seen a cardiologist. No prior
stress testing.
She received aspirin prior to my assessment and had an ECG performed by EMS which shows t-wave
inversions in the anterior leads.

presents to the ED for evaluation of chest pain. While she has a limited medical history without
significant cardiovascular risk factors, she has a very concerning family history and a markedly abnormal
ECG. Given these considerations, I have high suspicion for ACS as the etiology of her chest pain. Chest x-
ray was obtained to assess for alternative etiologies and was unremarkable. Initial troponin noted to be
elevated though declining. Pain also resolved. Cardiology consulted, plan for admission for further
cardiac w/u.

consideration of IV antibiotics

The patient is a 38-year-old female presenting with chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and neck, associated with nausea and exertional dyspnea. She has a family history of early cardiac events, with her mother having a heart attack at 42 and her father dying suddenly at 50. She has had multiple episodes of similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency. Her ECG shows T-wave inversions in the anterior leads, and her initial troponin levels were elevated. These symptoms and findings are highly suggestive of acute coronary syndrome (ACS), despite her relatively young age and lack of personal history of cardiovascular disease. The physician's impression is NSTEMI (non-ST elevated myocardial infarction), which is a type of ACS. 

[Highly suspicious (2)]

Visit Type: Urgent visit
Preferred Language: Spanish
Chief Concern: right lower extremity wound
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# RLE wound
1 week ago, the patient scratched her shin and obtained an small abrasion. She has since been working in
her garden a lot, and noticed that her abrasion is not healing. She thinks that it is getting larger, redder
and more painful. Has been putting some antibiotic ointment on it and wrapping it tightly, thinks that is is
now also oozing. Denies trying any medications for it. Has not had anything like this before.
- no fevers at home
- has with some palpitations at baseline due to anxiety
- denies lighteadeness or dizziness
- denies falls
C/f cellulitis
Start antibiotics with doxy and Keflex
F/u 1 week
If not improving, go the ED
Review of Systems
As per HPI
____________________________________________________________________________
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: She has a past medical history of Anxiety (since childhood)
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: None
FAMILY HISTORY: family history includes heart disease in her mother
SOCIAL HISTORY: Denies smoking, alcohol or illicits
Allergies :is allergic to penicillins - tolerates cephalosporins.
Medications:
• acetaminophen (TYLENOL) 500
mg tablet
Take 2 tablets (1,000 mg total) by mouth
every 6 (six) hours as needed.
• hydrOXYzine (VISTARIL) 100 mg
capsule
TAKE ONE CAPSULE BY MOUTH FOUR TIMES DAILY AS
NEEDED FOR ITCHING OR anxiety
PHYSICAL EXAM
Vitals:
BP: 120/62
Pulse: 76
Resp: 17
Temp: 98.9 °F (37.2 °C)
General: NAD
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI
CV: rrr, normal s1 and s2, no murmur
Resp: CTABL, not tachypneic or in respiratory distress
Neuro: alert and oriented x4, no focal weakness
MSK/Skin: No peripheral edema, large red, swollen wound on RLE, TTP
ASSESSMENT/PLAN
Sofia Rodriquez-Colon is a 38 y.o. female with past medical history significant for anxiety who presents
today for urgent visit.
# Cellulitis
RLE has become much more painful. Wound appears infected with no systemic symptoms.
- vitals and HPI not suggestive of SIRS or sepsis, thus will elect to treat as outpatient for now
- provided patient and VNA with anticipatory guidance and when to go to the ED
- CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP
- Start doxycycline and Keflex
- f/u in 1 week to evaluate wound. If the wound has wider area of involvement, or if pain is worsening,
or if there is more drainage, would consider referral to the ED for more expedited workup and
consideration of IV antibiotics
- patient agreeable with plan of care

no vomiting or diarrhea. Pain radiates into her left shoulder and neck. She reports multiple episodes of
similar pain over the last few days, increasing in frequency. Had trouble sleeping last night due to pain.
Has been having some exertional dyspnea climbing stairs for the last few weeks.
She denies any other shortness of breath.

She does not have a personal history of CAD however she reports her mother had a heart attack when
she was 42 and her father died suddenly at 50.
She denies any history of DVT/PE.
She has a primary care doctor but hasn’t seen them recently. Has never seen a cardiologist. No prior
stress testing.
She received aspirin prior to my assessment and had an ECG performed by EMS which shows t-wave
inversions in the anterior leads.
